column5: United States. During 1788
column6: pioneers to the Ohio Country established Marietta as the first permanent settlement of the new United States in the Territory Northwest of the River Ohio. Marietta is located in southeastern Ohio at the mouth of the Muskingum River at its confluence with the Ohio River 11 miles northeast of Parkersburg

column1: It is the second-largest city in the Parkersburg-Marietta-Vienna
column2: WV-OH Combined Statistical Area. The private
column3: nonsectarian liberal arts Marietta College is located here. It was a station on the Underground Railroad before the Civil War. Marietta is also the site of the prehistoric Marietta Earthworks
column4: a Hopewell complex more than 1500 years old
column5: whose Great Mound and other major monuments were preserved by the earliest settlers in parks such as the Mound Cemetery.

column2: −81.450506).According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 8.75 square miles (22.66 km2)
column4: of which 8.43 square miles (21.83 km2) is land and 0.32 square miles (0.83 km2) is water.The Muskingum River and Duck Creek flow into the Ohio River at Marietta. The area is part of the Appalachian Plateau which covers the eastern half of Ohio. The Appalachian Plateau consists of steep hills and valleys and is the most rugged area in the state. The area is within the ecoregion of the Western Allegheny Plateau. This portion of the state has some of Ohio's most abundant mineral deposits.

column1: The climate in this area is characterized by humid summers
column3: and evenly distributed precipitation throughout the year. According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column4: Marietta has a Humid continental climate
column5: abbreviated "Dfa" on climate maps.

column1: Succeeding Indigenous cultures lived along the Ohio River and its tributaries for thousands of years. Among them were more than one culture who built earthwork mounds
column2: monuments which generally expressed their cosmology
column3: often with links to astronomical events.

column2: the Hopewell culture built the multi-earthwork complex on the terrace east of the Muskingum River near its mouth with the Ohio. It is now known as the Marietta Earthworks. Developed over many years
column3: it had a large enclosed square
column4: within which were four platform mounds
column5: used for ceremonial purposes and elite residential; another square
column6: and a larger conical mound used for burials. A walled
column7: graded path led to the river's edge. By the time of the historic tribes
column9: the purposes and makers of the monuments were no longer known.

column1: French explorers entered this area in the 18th century
column2: and in 1749 buried numerous leaden plates to mark their claim to the Ohio Country (which they called the Illinois Territory
column3: as they had more settlements near the Mississippi River.) They later ceded their territory east of the Mississippi to Great Britain after the French and Indian War. Two of their plates were discovered in the Marietta area in 1798
column4: and one was replicated for what is known as the French monument

column2: the future U.S. president George Washington
column3: then a surveyor
column4: began exploring large tracts of land west of his native Virginia. During the Revolutionary War
column5: Washington told his friend General Rufus Putnam of the beauty he had seen in his travels through the Ohio Valley and of his ideas for settling the territory.  In the summer of 1781

column9: near present-day Marietta.After the American Revolutionary War
column10: the United States sold or granted large tracts of land to stimulate development in this area. Marietta was founded by settlers from New England who were investors in the Ohio Company of Associates. It was the first of numerous New England settlements in what was then the Northwest Territory. These New Englanders
column12: were descended from the Puritan English colonists who had settled New England in the 1600s and were primarily Congregationalists. The first church constructed in Marietta was a Congregationalist church
column13: founded around 1786. Before the mid-1790s services were held at the fort or in Munsell's Hall at nearby Point Harmar. In 1798 the Muskingum Academy was built on the site of the 19th century Marietta Congregationalist Church. The academy building served for both educational and religious purposes.

column2: the newly formed United States had little cash but plenty of land. Eager to develop additional lands
column3: the new government decided to pay veterans of the Revolution with warrants for land in the Northwest Territory
column4: which was organized under federal authority in 1787 by the Northwest Ordinance. Competing states had agreed to end their claims to the lands; Pennsylvania and Virginia received some lands in a settlement. Arthur St. Clair was appointed by the president as governor of the new territory.

column1: The Ohio Company of Associates had supported provisions in the ordinance to allow veterans to use their warrants to purchase the land. They bought 1.5 million acres (6
column2: 100 km2) of land from Congress. On April 7
column4: 48 men of the Ohio Company of Associates
column5: led by General Putnam
column6: arrived at the confluence of the Muskingum and Ohio rivers. The site was on the east side of the Muskingum River
column8: a military outpost built three years prior.

column1: Bringing with them the first government sanctioned by the US for this area

column30: who had aided the colonies in their battle for independence from Great Britain.

column2: the United States signed the Treaty of Fort Harmar with several Indigenous tribes that occupied areas of the Northwest Territory
column3: to settle issues related to trade
column4: as well as the boundary between their lands and United States settlement. The US did not address the Indigenous people's major grievance about American settlers moving into their lands
column5: particularly in the Western Reserve
column6: where there were disputes over land. Although Congress authorized Governor Arthur St. Clair to give land back to the Indigenous people
column7: he did not do so. Conflict increased as the Indigenous people tried to push the settlers out. After years of warfare in the region
column8: they were defeated. The US signed the Treaty of Greenville (1795) with the Indigenous people
column9: which secured the safety of settlers to leave the forts and develop their farms.

column1: The settlers held services regularly and chartered the first church in 1799. It was a Congregational institution; its charter was unusually inclusive due to the varied religious backgrounds of its members. The congregation constructed the first church building in 1807. The original church burned in 1905 and another constructed in its place in 1906. The church
column2: First Congregational Church United Church of Christ
column3: is the longest continuously worshiping congregation west of the Alleghenies.Education was important to the settlers
column4: many of whom had been officers during the Revolution. During that first winter
column5: they began a basic school for the children at Campus Martius. In 1797
column6: settlers founded Muskingum Academy. The town had numerous abolitionists
column7: and Ephraim Cutler was instrumental as a state delegate in 1802 at the state convention in swaying the vote for the state to be free of slavery.

column1: Townspeople organized and chartered Marietta College in 1835. It was used as a station on the Underground Railroad to help slaves escape from the South. Ohio University was founded earlier in Athens
column2: on land reserved for public education under the Northwest Ordinance.

column1: The settlers preserved the Great Mound
column3: by planning their own cemetery around it. They also preserved the two largest platform mounds
column4: which they called Capitolinus and Quadrophenus. The former was developed as the site for the city library. As of 1900
column5: the Mound Cemetery had the highest number of burials of Revolutionary War officers in the nation
column6: indicating the nature of the generation that settled Marietta.Marietta's location on two major navigable rivers made it ideal for industry and commerce. Boat building was one of the early industries. Artisans built oceangoing vessels and sailed them downriver to the Mississippi and south to New Orleans and the Gulf of Mexico. In less than two decades after settlement
column8: and was also constructed here. Brick factories and sawmills supplied materials for homes and public buildings. An iron mill
column10: provided rails for the growing railroad industry; the Marietta Chair Factory made furniture.

column1: Interest in the prehistoric culture that built the Marietta Earthworks continued. The complex was surveyed and drawn by Ephraim George Squier and Edwin Hamilton Davis
column2: whose large project on numerous prehistoric mounds throughout the Ohio and Mississippi valleys was published by the Smithsonian Institution in 1848 as Ancient Monuments of the Mississippi Valley. It was the first book published by the Smithsonian. Their drawing to the right shows the plan of the original complex
column3: which "included a large square enclosure surrounding four flat-topped pyramidal mounds
column4: another smaller square
column5: and a circular enclosure with a large burial mound at its center." The walled
column7: called by the settlers the Sacra Via
column8: led from the largest enclosure to the lower river's edge. This pathway was destroyed in 1843 during mid-nineteenth century development.

column1: Local development began with the Belpre and Cincinnati Railroad (B&C); it was founded in 1845. It was intended to connect from Belpre
column3: the next town downriver
column4: to a planned Baltimore and Ohio Railroad (B&O) spur to Parkersburg. But
column5: for years
column6: the Virginia government did not allow the B&O to construct track south of Wheeling. In 1851 developers changed the Ohio state terminus to Marietta and changed the name of the railroad to the Marietta and Cincinnati Railroad that year. The right-of-way for an alternate connection to the B&O extended upriver from Marietta to Bellaire
column7: Ohio. The M&C was bankrupt by 1857
column8: but construction of track continued west to reach Cincinnati. The first through-train from Cincinnati ran on April 9
column9: 1857. The M&C got out of bankruptcy in 1860.In 1871
column10: the Ohio Valley Railroad was formed and for the next two years built tracks going north for 103 miles. Their home office was in Marietta
column11: with treasurer offices in Pittsburgh. The Ohio Valley railroad was reorganized as the Marietta and Cleveland. The Pennsylvania Railroad in its expansion later purchased the railroad and its right-of-way between Marietta and Bellaire.Passengers traveling between Marietta and Parkersburg
column12: Virginia (now West Virginia) had to take a steamboat for the 14 miles between the two towns and transfer. With help from the B&O and the Baltimore City Council
column13: the Union Railroad finally connected Marietta to Belpre
column14: Ohio in 1860. Later absorbed by the B&O
column15: this section of track is still in operation (2008)
column16: with unit coal trains providing most of the traffic.The planned bridge from Parkersburg across the Ohio River to Belpre was finally built 1868–1870 by the B&O
column17: as part of its main line from Baltimore to St. Louis
column18: Missouri. This cut Marietta off from traffic and trade
column19: although it retained local and Ohio service. In the early 20th century
column20: 24 passenger trains served Marietta each day
column21: most of which ran on the PRR tracks.William P. Cutler was a major figure in the M&C. He also backed the Union Railroad and the Marietta
column23: among other local railroads. Cutler served as General Manager and as President of the M&C for many years.In 1860
column24: oil was first drilled in the Marietta region. Oil booms in 1875 and 1910 made investors rich
column25: who constructed numerous lavish houses in town
column26: of which many still stand. The Dawes brothers of Marietta founded the Pure Oil Company. All four brothers became nationally prominent businessmen and/or politicians: Charles Gates Dawes
column28: Beman Gates Dawes and Henry May Dawes. Charles Dawes was elected in 1924 with President Calvin Coolidge to serve as the 30th Vice President of the United States (1925–1929). In 1925
column29: he shared the Nobel Peace Prize
column30: based on his work on the Dawes Plan and relieving an international crisis in 1923 related to German reparations after World War I.

column2: the first Putnam Street Bridge was opened to connect Marietta to Fort Harmar. It provided the first free crossing of the Muskingum River.

column1: As transportation advanced along railroads and highways
column2: Marietta was initially passed by. From 1868–1870

column2: the Pennsylvania Railroad expanded in the late 19th century and had a station in Marietta
column3: running 26 daily trains between Marietta and Pittsburgh. After WWII passenger service decreased as the railroads restructured and the federal government invested in highway construction. The last rail passenger service ended in 1953. Marietta was relatively isolated from new travel routes until 1967
column4: when I-77 was opened with close access to the city.

column2: the Sons and Daughters of Pioneer Rivermen was established in Marietta during the Great Depression to celebrate the city's substantial river history and its people. Two years later the Ohio River Museum was opened. In 1972

column1: Marietta is home of the longest-running ferromanganese refinery in North America
column3: the only ferromanganese refinery in the United States until recently
column4: and leader in Manganese emissions.

column1: The city of Marietta uses the mayor-council form of government. The mayor is a full-time position; the seven city council members and the city council president are all part-time positions.

The president of council presides over all regular and special meetings of the council although he has no vote therein except in case of a tie. The president of council appoints all council members to the standing committees and is responsible for several city board and commission appointments as well as in charge of the records of city council. The president of council oversees all the day-to-day operations of the clerk of council. The president of council serves as the liaison to the city administration. When the mayor is absent from the city or unable to perform his duties
column2: the president of council shall become acting mayor and shall have the same powers and perform the same duties as the mayor. The president of council is elected to a two-year term.

column1: Three at-large council members represent the entire city of Marietta. All members of council chair a standing committee and serve on two other standing committees. At-large council members sponsor and introduce legislation and have a vote. All council members are elected to two-year terms.

Four ward council members represent each of the city's four wards. All members of council chair a standing committee and serve on two other standing committees. Ward council members sponsor and introduce legislation and have a vote. All council members are elected to two-year terms.
A president pro tem is chosen by the members of the council from among the council to serve as the president pro tem (acting president of council) in the absence
column2: disability or when the president of council is serving as acting mayor.

column1: The clerk of council is responsible for recording council meeting minutes
column2: reading the legislation at council meetings and performing the daily operations of the council office. The council clerk is appointed by the council and is supervised by the president of council.

column1: Joshua D. Schlicher is the current Mayor of Marietta. A Republican

the Ohio River Sternwheel Festival has been held on the weekend after Labor Day in September. 2005 was the 30th anniversary of the event
column3: which attracts dozens of Sternwheelers to the banks of the Ohio River near downtown Marietta. The Festival includes performances from musical artists
column4: Sternwheel races
column5: and a large fireworks display; it attracts thousands of visitors from across the country.

column1: The Riverfront Roar powerboat races are held annually in July. The event includes Formula 2 and Formula 3 powerboat racing along the Ohio River.
Marietta Civil War Reenactment is also held at the end of September. It includes Union and Confederate reenactors battling across the scenic Muskingum River.
Goodfest is held at Goodfellows Park; this local music festival for teenagers features local musicians in a drug & alcohol-free environment.
A number of rowing regattas are held throughout the spring. Chief among them Marietta High School's Ralph Lindamood Memorial Regatta and the Marietta Invitational Regatta hosted by Marietta College
column2: which brings some of the nation's fastest college rowing programs to the Muskingum River. In the fall season
column3: the "Head of the Muskingum" head race is held
column4: again drawing rowing teams from across the country. The race is run over a 3–3.5 mile course starting in Devola
column5: Ohio and ending at Marietta College's Lindamood-Van Voorhis Boathouse.
